div.p: We describe in some detail our numerical treatment of Neubergerâ€™s lattice Dirac operator as implemented in a practical application. We discuss the improvements we have found to accelerate the numerical computations and give an estimate of the expense when using this operator in practice.

Today, we believe that the world of quarks and gluons is described theoretically by quantum chromodynamics (QCD). This model shows a number of non-perturbative aspects that cannot be adequately addressed by approximation schemes such as perturbation theory. The only way to evaluate QCD, addressing both its perturbative and non-perturbative aspects at the same time, is lattice QCD. In this approach the theory is put on a 4-dimensional Euclidean space-time lattice of finite physical length Lğ¿italic-LL, with a non-vanishing value of the lattice spacing ağ‘italic-aa. Having only a finite number of grid points, physical quantities can be computed numerically by solving a high-dimensional integral by Monte Carlo methods, making use of importance sampling.

The introduction of a lattice spacing regularizes the theory and is an intermediate step in the computation of physical observables. Eventually, the regularization has to be removed and the value of the lattice spacing has to be sent to zero to reach the target theory, i.e. continuum QCD. In fact, in conventional formulations of lattice QCD [2], the introduction of the lattice spacing renders the theory on the lattice somewhat different from the continuum analogue and a number of properties of the continuum theory are only very difficult and cumbersome to establish in the lattice regularized theory. One of the main reasons for this difficulty is that in conventional lattice QCD the regularization breaks a particular symmetry of the continuum theory, which plays a most important role there, namely chiral symmetry.

However, the last few years have seen a major breakthrough in that we now have formulations of lattice QCD that have an exact lattice chiral symmetry [6]. In this approach, many properties of continuum QCD are preserved even at a non-vanishing value of the lattice spacing [3, 4, 5, 6, 7]. This development followed the rediscovery [8] of the so-called Ginspargâ€“Wilson (GW) relation [9] which is fulfilled by any operator with the exact lattice chiral symmetry of [6]. It is not the aim of this contribution to discuss the physics consequences of the GW relation. We have to refer the interested reader to reviews [10, 11] about these topics. Here we would like to discuss the numerical treatment of a particular lattice operator that satisfies the GW relation, namely Neubergerâ€™s solution [5]. This solution has a complicated structure and is challenging to implement numerically. Thus, the large theoretical advantage of an operator satisfying the GW relation must be weighed against the very demanding computational effort required to implement it.

This contribution is organized as follows. After discussing Neubergerâ€™s lattice Dirac operator we want to show how we evaluated the operator in our practical application [12] and what kind of improvements we found to accelerate the numerical computations. For alternative ideas for improvements, see the contributions of H. Neuberger [13] and A. Borici [14] to this workshop. We finally give some estimates of the computational expense of using Neubergerâ€™s operator.

div.p: Through the appearance of the square root in eq.Â (2), all points on the lattice are connected with one another, giving rise to a very complicated, multi-neighbour action. However, the application of Dğ·italic-DD to a vector Î¦Î¦Phi\Phi will only contain applications of Ağ´italic-AA or Aâ€ â¢Asuperscriptğ´â€ ğ´italic-A POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:dagger POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-AA^{\dagger}A on this vector. Since these matrices are sparse, as only nearest-neighbour interactions are involved, we will never have to store the whole matrix.

In the computation of physical quantities, the inverse of Dğ·italic-DD, applied to a given vector, is generically needed. Hence one faces the problem of having to compute a vector X=D-1â¢Î·ğ‘‹superscriptğ·1ğœ‚italic-X RELOP:equals italic-D POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-etaX=D^{-1}\eta, with Î·ğœ‚italic-eta\eta a prescribed vector (the â€œsourceâ€) as required by the particular problem under investigation. Fortunately, a number of efficiently working algorithms for computing X=D-1â¢Î·ğ‘‹superscriptğ·1ğœ‚italic-X RELOP:equals italic-D POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-etaX=D^{-1}\eta are known, such as conjugate gradient, BiCGstab, or variants thereof [17]. In conventional approaches to lattice QCD an operator D~~ğ·OVERACCENT:tilde ARG:start italic-D ARG:end\tilde{D} is used that is very similar to the matrix Ağ´italic-AA in eq.Â (1). Computing the vector X~=D~-1â¢Î·~ğ‘‹superscript~ğ·1ğœ‚OVERACCENT:tilde ARG:start italic-X ARG:end RELOP:equals OVERACCENT:tilde ARG:start italic-D ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-eta\tilde{X}=\tilde{D}^{-1}\eta requires a number nitersubscriptğ‘›iteritalic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start iter POSTSUBSCRIPT:endn_{\rm iter} of iterations of some particular method, say BiCGstab. Employing Neubergerâ€™s operator Dğ·italic-DD in computing X=D-1â¢Î·ğ‘‹superscriptğ·1ğœ‚italic-X RELOP:equals italic-D POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-etaX=D^{-1}\eta, it turns out that the number of iterations needed is of the same order of magnitude as when using D~~ğ·OVERACCENT:tilde ARG:start italic-D ARG:end\tilde{D}. At the same time, in each of these iterations, the square root has to be evaluated. When this is done by some polynomial approximation, it is found that the required degree of this polynomial is roughly of the same order as the number of iterations needed for computing the vector Xğ‘‹italic-XX. Hence, with respect to the conventional case, the numerical effort is squared and the price to pay for using the operator Dğ·italic-DD is high.

On the other hand, any solution of the Ginspargâ€“Wilson relation gives us a tool by which particular problems in lattice QCD can be studied, which would be extremely hard to address with conventional approaches. It is for these cases that the large numerical effort is justified, but clearly, we would like to have clever ideas coming from areas such as Applied Mathematics, to decrease the numerical expense or even overcome this bottleneck.

Whether alternative formulations, such as domain wall fermions, can help in this respect remains to be seen.
